newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HSBC, Hang Seng down on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: HSBC, Hang Seng down on profit-taking.

text.p: Shares of HSBC Holdings Plc and Hang Seng Bank Ltd fell on profit-taking on Tuesday after the banks reported strong yearly earnings growth on Monday, brokers said.
HSBC shares fell as much as HK$4.00 or 2.12 percent to HK$185 in early trade on volume of 939,615 shares before clawing back some ground. At 0300 GMT the stock was at $185.50.
Shares of Hang Seng Bank fell as much as HK$5.50 or 6.18 percent to HK$83.50 in early trade on volume of 1.87 million shares. It had also rebounded slightly by 0300 GMT to $84.50.
Brokers said investors took profits in HSBC after the bank met market expectations of a 25-percent growth in 1996 earnings to HK$37.59 billion.
"Investors were taking profit after the bank posted a profit which was in line with expectation," said Edwin Cheung, sales manager at Taiwan Securities.
Hang Seng Bank reported a 6.3 percent growth in 1996 annual earnings to HK$8.49 billion on Monday.

"Our estimation was already at the lower end of the market range of 15 to 20 percent, but it turned up much lower than we expected," said Sean Li, associate director at Amsteel Securities. "Its growth disappointed the market and its provision was also seen higher."
Brokers said a higher bad debt position of the bank and a gradual loss of marketshare in the mortgage sector also disappointed investors, and that helped to trigger selling.
